nodes.text: Large increases in Chinese manufacturing exports (the China trade shock) materially altered labor-market outcomes in developed countries and testing how labor markets adjust to such large trade shocks will change assessments of the gains and distributional costs of trade

Context: China experienced an unexpected, rapid export surge from the 1990s into the 2000s (WTO accession in 2001), transforming it into a global manufacturing exporter concentrated in labor-intensive goods

Method: Use gravity-based and instrumental-variables empirical strategies that exploit cross-industry and cross-region variation in pre-shock industry shares to measure local exposure to Chinese import competition (industry import-penetration and commuting-zone exposure), and supplement with input-output linkages and worker-level panel data

Claim: China's rise was supply-driven and idiosyncratic (catch-up from Mao-era isolation, privatization, SEZs, FDI and productivity growth), producing sectorally concentrated export growth rather than uniform expansion across industries

Claim: Because China specialized in manufacturing, the shock is effectively a large global supply shock to manufacturing with heterogeneous exposure across US industries and regions due to preexisting industry-location patterns

Assumption: Labor mobility across US regions is imperfect (slow geographic reallocation), especially for lower-skilled workers, so local labor markets can experience persistent shocks rather than immediate national equilibration

Evidence (industry level): Instrumented increases in import penetration from China are associated with statistically and economically significant declines in US manufacturing employment at the industry level (e.g., a one percentage point rise in penetration reduces industry employment by about 1.3 log points)

Method / Evidence: Construct commuting zone (CZ) exposure measures by pre-shock local industry shares and link CZ-level changes in imports per worker to CZ outcomes (employment, wages, transfers); instrument US import penetration with contemporaneous Chinese export growth to other high-income countries to isolate supply-driven variation

Method: Use input-output tables to capture upstream and downstream propagation of trade shocks and matched worker-employer longitudinal data (Social Security records) to measure individual career impacts

Result / Evidence (local and general equilibrium): Regions more exposed to Chinese import growth experienced large, persistent declines in manufacturing employment that translated into declines in overall local employment rates, higher unemployment and non-participation, modest population outflows, and limited offsetting job gains elsewhere; input-output spillovers amplify job losses

Result / Evidence (wages and transfers): CZs more exposed to Chinese imports show larger reductions in average wages concentrated at the bottom of the wage distribution and substantial increases in public transfer receipts (medical, disability, retirement, income assistance), while Trade Adjustment Assistance payments are small in dollar magnitude

Result / Evidence (worker-level): Workers initially employed in industries that became more exposed to Chinese imports experienced lower lifetime earnings, greater job churn, higher receipt of disability and other transfers, and often moved to other exposed industries or remained locally exposed rather than rapidly re-sorting into protected jobs

Conclusion: The China trade shock produced sizable short- and medium-run distributional and adjustment costs concentrated in trade-exposed industries and local labor markets; adjustment is slow, spatially concentrated, and only partially offset by other channels, implying that standard aggregate trade welfare calculations must account for localized, persistent costs and mobility frictions
